questions.explaination: You are doing an infiltration of a specific tooth, rather than a field block or a nerve block, which would anesthetize more teeth at one time. In this case, you would place the topical agent in the vestibule of the specific tooth and nerve branch the dentist plans to work on.
questions.options1: Near the mesial of the canine tooth, for a field block
questions.options2: In the vestibule, for a posterior superior alveolar nerve block
questions.options3: In the vestibule, for an anterior superior alveolar nerve block
questions.options4: In the vestibule, near the isolated nerve branch
questions.qsn: #8 needs to be infiltrated for scaling and root planing.  Where is the topical anesthetic placed?

questions.explaination: The chlorine based in-office solutions need to be prepared daily. Chlorine dioxide, part of the chlorine family, is a poor surface cleaner. However, that is not true for the rest of the chlorine category.
questions.options1: Diluted solutions need to be prepared daily
questions.qsn: When starting a new job in a dental office, you notice that the staff does not use surface barriers and uses a chlorine based surface disinfectant. What is a disadvantage of using this type of disinfectant?

questions.explaination: It is important to note that radiography is not the best when trying to get an accurate image of the TMJ joint. That is because there are many bony structures that obstruct the view. It is recommended that a patient get cone beam imaging to get a more accurate image.
questions.qsn: What type of radiography is best for examining the temporomandibular joint?

questions.explaination: The panoramic x-ray is considered to be an extraoral x-ray. The film is on the outside of the mouth and exposed by rotating around the head of the patient. The patient often bites down on a stick for stability, but nothing else is placed inside of the oral cavity.
questions.qsn: The dentist wants you to take a panoramic x-ray to evaluate a joint two dimensionally.  What type of x-ray is the panoramic

questions.explaination: The patient chair button would be considered a touch surface, considering the office is not using plastic barriers to protect the button from contamination. It could also be considered a transfer surface if there was more than one button or key pad in the room.
questions.qsn: A chair button, which is used when positioning a patient in a dental chair, does not have a plastic barrier.  What type of surface is the chair button considered?

questions.explaination: You should always wear rubber gloves when handling contaminated materials and using chemicals. Latex gloves can break down with certain chemicals and can easily be punctured.
questions.options2: Goggles, mask and scrubs, face shield
questions.options3: Mask, goggles protective gown and rubber gloves
questions.options4: Non-latex gloves, protective gown, mask and goggles
questions.qsn: What is the correct personal protective equipment you should wear when cleaning a treatment room after use?

questions.explaination: 2 = moderate mobility. Every tooth has mobility, but periodontal disease and bone loss can make certain teeth more mobile than others. 0 = normal, 1 = slight mobility, 3 = extreme mobility.
questions.qsn: After recording all of the periodontal pocket numbers, you check each tooth for mobility. On #29, there is moderate mobility. What do you record in the chart?

questions.explaination: The patient has open-bite. This type of bite in common among thumb suckers. To correct this type of bite, orthodontics should be considered.
questions.qsn: When performing an intraoral exam, a dentist begins evaluating a patient's bite. She notices that the posterior teeth are touching, but the anterior lack vertical overlap. What is this referred to?

questions.explaination: Irreversible hydrocolloid aka alginate, is used when making preliminary and final impressions. It can be used to make whitening trays and study models.
questions.qsn: What type of material is alginate?

questions.explaination: Acrylate resin is the material used in sealants. It can be highly allergic to a patient with this type of allergy. If skin contact occurs, the area exposed needs to be thoroughly wash and rinsed with water. Acrylates can penetrate gloves. Phosphoric acid is in the etching material, not the sealant material.
questions.qsn: If a patient has an allergic reaction to sealant material, what type of allergy do they have?

questions.explaination: The sealant material needs to be carefully dispensed, avoiding bubbles. If one does occur, try to manipulate the bubbles out of the working area with explorer. If a bubble still does exist, add sealant material to fill in the gap. If isolation was lost, etch again to add sealant.
questions.options1: Moisture contamination - need better isolation during placement of sealant.
questions.options2: Applied too much sealant material - sealant must be removed and replaced.
questions.options3: Vigorous scrubbing during application - add more sealant. Etch again if necessary.
questions.options4: Applied too much sealant material - needs to have bite adjusted.
questions.qsn: Once sealant material has been placed and checked for retention, you notice that one area of sealant has a small bubble. What is the cause and solution?

questions.explaination: There are six links in the chain of infection. If one link is broken, infection cannot occur. It is important to understand this chain in regards to infection control throughout the dental office. It is also important to understand the types of infections you may be exposed to in the dental office.
questions.options1: Infectious agent, reservoir, mode of transmission, portal of entry and susceptible host
questions.options2: Infectious agent, reservoir, mode of transmission, portal of exit and susceptible host
questions.options3: Infectious agent, reservoir, portal of exit, mode of transmission, portal of entry and susceptible host
questions.options4: Infectious agent, reservoir, mode of transmission and susceptible host
questions.qsn: What is the correct order of links in regards to the chain of infection?

questions.explaination: When running in a steam autoclave for 15 or 30 minutes, it should always reach the temperature of 250 degree Fahrenheit. However, when running on shorter cycles or a flash steam, of three to ten minutes, you will need a temperature of 273 degrees Fahrenheit.
questions.qsn: You are setting up the sterilization room in the morning, before patients arrive.Your next job in the sterilization room is performing the daily testing on the steam autoclave. Your autoclave is set to run 15 minutes. What temperature does the autoclave need to reach in order to be effective in sterilization?

questions.explaination: Calibration is done by qualified technician in intervals regulated by each state. There are many tests a dental assistant can perform to make sure that the equipment is working properly, such as the output of x-rays, kilo voltage and focal point spot tests.
questions.options1: Test of the output of x-rays
questions.qsn: The dental office you work at is doing their yearly testing on all dental x-ray equipment. The dentist puts you in charge of managing the testing of the equipment. Though you can perform in-office testing on all of the x-ray equipment, which of the following needs to be done by a qualified technician?

questions.explaination: Digital radiography's main infection control problem is cross-contamination of surfaces due to blood and saliva. It is important to follow the CDC regulations regarding proper handling of the digital devices.
questions.qsn: What is the main concern involving infection control in radiography?

questions.explaination: Type IV is often related to a contact reaction that involves the immune system. It is the chemicals used to process the gloves that cause the allergic reaction. The rash appears 48-72 hours after contact.  Type I is the most serious of latex allergies as it involves a reaction to the proteins in latex. A response occurs within 2-3 minutes of contact. The patient could exhibit coughing, shortness of breath or anaphylaxis.
questions.qsn: A patient notes on a health history that he is allergic to latex. He also states that he breaks out in a rash around his mouth when latex gloves are used. What class of allergic reaction is this?

questions.explaination: It is impossible to create a latex free dental office, as there is latex in some of the products and supplies that are use. It is important to understand that latex protein can be present in the air, so it is important to schedule these patients first thing in the morning, when the proteins are at a minimum. It is also important that all PPE and exam rooms be latex-free while the patient is in the office, even if it not the treatment room the patient is seated in.
questions.options3: First statement is true.  Second statement is false.
questions.options4: First statement is false. Second statement is true.
questions.qsn: A dental practice is to create a latex free dental office to avoid allergic reactions in those patients allergic to latex.  Patients with latex allergies do not need to be scheduled for treatment at any particular time of the day.

questions.explaination: Using a black pen with a single line allows another user to read the incorrect entry. Using your initials and dating the entry allows the reader to know who made the mistake an when that mistake was corrected.
questions.options1: Use a black pen and make a single line through the incorrect entry
questions.options2: Use a red pen and make a single line through the incorrect entry
questions.options3: Use a black pen and make a single line through the incorrect entry. Also, initial and date
questions.options4: Use a red pen and make a single line through the incorrect entry. Also, initial and date
questions.qsn: You are updating a patient record by recording all of their previous restorations. You accidentally write "composite filling" instead of "amalgam filling". When correcting an entry in a patient chart, you should:

questions.explaination: Gingivitis is a sign and symptom of periodontal disease, not a risk factor. Gingivitis is inflammation in the gingival tissue and can often be reversed with good oral care. Smoking, diabetes and HIV/AIDS are al risks factors that can contribute to periodontal disease. These risks factors can alter the body's response in control the bacteria that causes periodontal disease
questions.qsn: Which of the following is not a risk factor of periodontal disease?

questions.explaination: No PPE is needed when duplicating x-rays, as no chemicals are involved. The duplicating machine should be placed in an area that is considered clean and sterile. It should not be placed in an area where contaminated chemicals or x-rays may come into contact with the machine.
questions.qsn: When duplicating x-rays, you need to be in a dark room. What type of infection control is needed?

questions.explaination: A patient with HYPERtension would be contraindicated for the air polisher. The polishing solution contains sodium bicarbonate, which could cause ankyloses. It should never be used on a person with a heart condition.
questions.options2: A patient on a sodium restricted diet
questions.qsn: All of the following patients have contraindications that would preclude the use of an air polisher EXCEPT one. Which one is the exception?

questions.explaination: Bell's palsy causes loss of movement to muscles due to lesions in the facial nerve. This condition is bilateral and usually is only temporary, though it may take several weeks prior to returning to normal use.
questions.qsn: A patient is experiencing symptoms related to Bell's palsy. Which cranial nerve is suffering from a motor deficit?

questions.explaination: Calcium is mobilized in and out of the bloodstream during bone remodeling. This allows new bone formation to occur in areas of the body where it is needed.
questions.qsn: What is mobilized in and out of the blood during bone remodeling?

questions.explaination: The trigeminal mandibular nerve passes through the foramen ovale of the sphenoid bone.
questions.qsn: Which cranial nerve passes through the foramen ovale of the sphenoid bone?

questions.explaination: The foramen rotundum is the opening that conveys the maxillary branch of the trigeminal nerve.
questions.qsn: The maxillary branch of the trigeminal nerve passes through the ______.

questions.explaination: The vagus nerve, or cranial nerve X is the longest of all cranial nerves. It reaches areas of the head and neck as well as the heart and stomach.
questions.qsn: Which cranial nerve is the longest and extends to the trunk of the body?

questions.explaination: The trigeminal ganglion does not have an optic division. Its divisions include the opthalmic, mandibular and maxillary, which enter in by the superior orbital fissure, foramen ovale and foramen rotundum.
questions.qsn: The trigeminal ganglion of the fifth (V) trigeminal nerve has three divisions. Which of the following is NOT a division of the trigeminal ganglion?

questions.explaination: The lymphatic system filters fluids and returns them to the bloodstream from various body tissues. It parallels the venous blood vessels.
questions.qsn: What parallels the venous blood vessels and returns filtered fluids to the bloodstream?

questions.explaination: Desmosomes are the cell-to-cell attachments in ameloblasts, which are responsible for forming tooth enamel.
questions.qsn: What type of cell-to-cell attachments are found in enamel-forming ameloblasts?

questions.explaination: Cytoplasm is the aqueous, translucent gel that is enclosed in a cell by a cell membrane. It is the liquid housing that contains other cellular particles and allows them to move about within the cell.
questions.qsn: What is the homogenous, translucent gel enclosed in a cell by the cell membrane?

questions.explaination: The oral cavity tissues such as the buccal mucosa and gingival mucosa are lined with stratisfied squamous epithelia, the shorter, flatter squamous cells found in multiple layers at the surface of the oral cavity tissues.
questions.qsn: Which type of epithelia lines the oral cavity?

questions.explaination: The occipoital bone is the bone on the posterior lower portion of the skull.
questions.qsn: Which cranial bone is the single bone located in the most posterior portion of the skull?

questions.explaination: The masseter is the most superficially located muscle used in mastication and is the strongest muscle used.
questions.qsn: Which muscle of mastication is superficially located and one of the strongest muscles?

questions.explaination: Mandibular second molars have shallower mesial root concavities that are not as prominent as the other teeth listed.
questions.qsn: Which tooth has a mesial root concavity that is not as prominent?

questions.explaination: The maxillary first premolar is the only premolar to have two roots, and it's furcation is toward the apical 1/3 to 1/2 of the tooth.
questions.qsn: Which tooth has a furcation that is in the apical third to 1/2 of the tooth?

questions.explaination: Class III occlusion is when the mesiobuccal groove of the mandibular first molar is mesial to the mesiobuccal cusp of the maxillary first permanent molar.
questions.qsn: A patient's mandibular first permanent molar's mesiobuccal groove is in a mesial relationship to the mesiobuccal cusp of the maxillary first permanent molar. What classification of occlusion is this?

questions.explaination: The maxillary first molar has three roots, with the lingual root being longer than the others, extending past the lingual surface of the tooth's crown.
questions.qsn: Which tooth has a long lingual root that usually extends beyond the lingual surface of the crown?

questions.explaination: Maxillary lateral incisors are the only incisor teeth to sometimes have a palatoradicular groove that extends from the crown to the root on the lingual surface.
questions.qsn: Which tooth may have a lingual groove extending from the crown to the root?

questions.explaination: 20-30 grams of fiber each day is the recommended daily adult intake for healthy individuals.
questions.qsn: What is the recommended fiber intake each day for an adult?

questions.explaination: 70-120 mg/100mL blood is a healthy blood glucose level and is the level that a controlled diabetic or other healthy individual should measure within.
questions.qsn: A healthy blood glucose level range is __________ mg/100mL blood.

questions.explaination: Starch is the complex carbohydrate that comes from plant storage in the form of glucose.
questions.qsn: Which complex carbohydrate is made up of the plant form of glucose?

questions.explaination: 5.5 pH is the acidic level at which decalcification and demineralization of tooth enamel begins to occur.
questions.qsn: Decalcification and demineralization of tooth enamel begins at what pH?

questions.explaination: Xylitol is the sweetener found naturally in plants and can interfere with s.mutans metabolism, decreasing the demineralization of enamel.
questions.qsn: What sweetener is found in plants and can interfere with the metabolism of s. Mutans?

questions.explaination: 130 g/day is the recommended daily allowance for digestible carbohydrates in both healthy adults and children.
questions.qsn: What is the recommended daily allowance for digestible carbohydrates?

questions.explaination: Both statements are true. Carbohydrates are an energy source for the growth and repair of periodontal tissues. A firm texture of complex carbohydrates may increase circulation in gingival tissue. Firm carbohydrates stimulate the gum tissue during mastication.
questions.options2: The first statement is true, the second statement is false
questions.options3: The first statement is false, the second statement is true
questions.qsn: Carbohydrates are an energy source for the growth and repair of periodontal tissues. A firm texture of complex carbohydrates may increase circulation in gingival tissue.

questions.explaination: Yogurt is recommended for lactose intolerant patients, because the lactose is digested by the yogurt. It therefore makes a healthy snack and alternative to other dairy products such as ice cream.
questions.options2: The first statement is true, the second statement is false
questions.options3: The first statement is false, the second statement is true
questions.qsn: Yogurt is not recommended for lactose intolerant patients. Lactose intolerance may be due to a congenital absence of lactase.

questions.explaination: Neutrophils are associated with acute inflammation by acting against invading pathogens in the body.
questions.qsn: Which leukocyte is associated with acute inflammation?

questions.explaination: Naturally passive acquired immunity is when antibodies are passed from one individual to another. An example of this is when the mother passes her immunity on to her child during gestation.
questions.qsn: If an antibody is produced by an individual and passed on to another, such as a mother to her child, what type of immunity is this?

questions.explaination: Hepatitis A is transmitted through fecal-oral contamination, such as in contaminated food or water due to poor living conditions or lack of hygiene by food preparers.
questions.qsn: Which Hepatitis virus is transmitted through a fecal-oral route?

questions.explaination: Leukopenia is abnormally low levels of white blood cells and is a disease of the WBCs and bone marrow; It should not be confused with leukemia, which is cancer of the bone marrow or WBCs.
questions.qsn: Which disease of the bone marrow exhibits abnormally low levels of white blood cells (WBCs)?

questions.explaination: Mucositis is the inflammation and ulceration of mucous membranes that line the digestive tract, including the mucosa of the oral cavity. It is a common side effect in patients undergoing radiation therapy or chemotherapy.
questions.qsn: What is a common side effect of radiation and or chemotherapy that causes painful inflammation and ulceration of mucous membranes?

questions.explaination: Endospores are resistant to high temperatures and disinfectants, and may remain viable for an extended amount of time. Endospores are the primary reason for the need of higher levels of temperature during sterilization processes.
questions.qsn: What microorganism is resistant to high temperatures and disinfectants?

questions.explaination: Anaerobes require an absence of oxygen in order to survive. Other types of microbes may be able to function without oxygen or with limited oxygen, but anaerobes require ultimate absence of oxygen in order to survive.
questions.qsn: Which of the following microbes cannot perform or may be destroyed in the presence of oxygen?

questions.explaination: Nondirect contact is the infection transmission that involves touching a contaminated object, such as a touching a used instrument without wearing gloves while transporting it to the sterilization area.
questions.qsn: Infection transmission that involves touching a contaminated object is considered:

questions.explaination: Opportunistic infections are infections that affect immunocompromised persons such as an infant or older adult. This is due to the pathogen taking an "opportunity" when the person's immune system is compromised. Anyone may suffer from passive, acute or chronic infections.
questions.qsn: An infection that affects an immunocompromised person is considered:

questions.explaination: Viruses are the smallest and simplest infectious agent. They contain only RNA or DNA strands.
questions.qsn: What are the smallest and simplest infectious agents?

questions.explaination: Antibiotics such as penicillin or amoxicillin are chemotherapeutic compounds that will inhibit or kill bacteria and is produced by a bacterium.
questions.qsn: What is a natural chemotherapeutic compound that is produced by a bacterium and will inhibit or kill bacteria?

questions.explaination: Impetigo is a highly infectious condition that can be due to staph or strep infections, leaving pustules and itchy yellow scabs around the mouth and face. It is highly contagious.
questions.qsn: A highly infectious condition that leaves pustules and itchy yellow scabs around the mouth and face is called _______.

questions.explaination: Pallor of the gingiva is not a symptom of leukemia. Instead, gingiva will appear red and tender to the touch, as well as exhibit bruising and bleeding.
questions.qsn: Which of the following is NOT a sign of leukemia?

questions.explaination: Fibrous dysplasia is a bone disease which affects children and involves two types: Monostotic and Polyostotic. Both cause abnormal proliferation of fibrous connective tissues.
questions.qsn: What bone disease is most common in children and involves abnormal proliferation of fibrous connective tissues?

questions.explaination: Squamous cell carcinoma is the most common oral cancer, attributing for approximately 90% of all oral cancer cases.
questions.qsn: The most common form of oral cancer is:

questions.explaination: Coronary artery atherosclerosis is associated with periodontal disease. Decreasing periodontal disease symptoms through preventative and maintenance care will reduce the patient's risk factors.
questions.qsn: Which cardiovascular disease is associated with periodontal disease, placing an emphasis on improving oral health in an attempt to reduce the risk of disease?

questions.explaination: The first statement is true, the second statement is false. Local anesthetics containing vasoconstrictors should not be given to asthma patients because it may cause reduced oxygen flow in the body, but they may be administered to patients with emphysema.
questions.options3: The first statement is true, the second statement is false
questions.options4: The first statement is false, the second statement is true
questions.qsn: Local anesthetics containing vasoconstrictors should not be administered to asthma patients. It also should not be used for patients that suffer from emphysema.

questions.explaination: Petit mal seizures are simple, with jerking motions and no loss of consciousness. The patient is aware of their surroundings and is able to recount the episode without loss of memory.
questions.qsn: What type of seizure exhibits symptoms of jerking motions and no loss of consciousness?

questions.explaination: Lupus is a chronic disease that displays a "butterfly" pattern over the patient's face.
questions.qsn: What disease exhibits itself in a classic "butterfly" pattern rash over the patient's face?

questions.explaination: Abfractions are the wedge-shaped lesion along the cervical margin of the teeth, usually due to fatigue or flexing of the tooth. The excess flexing causes enamel to chip off of the tooth in this area, exposing the dentin.
questions.qsn: Wedge-shaped lesions along the cervical margin of the teeth are referred to as _________.

questions.explaination: Pyogenic granulomas is a reactive tissue hyperplasia related to hormonal changes, usually associated with pregnancy. This condition may also be called "pregnancy tumors."
questions.qsn: A condition of the oral tissues due to hormonal changes during pregnancy is called ____________.

questions.explaination: Amalgam tattoos are bluish discolorations of the oral mucosa due to leaking of particles from an amalgam filling directly into the mucosa. Therefore they may appear radiopaque on a radiograph.
questions.qsn: A discoloration of the oral mucosa that may have a radiopaque appearance.

questions.explaination: Eruption cysts usually involve primary tooth eruption and exhibit bluish tissue with swelling around the erupting tooth, hence the term "eruption cyst."
questions.qsn: Which cyst exhibits bluish swelling around a newly erupting crown, most common with the eruption of primary teeth?

questions.explaination: Both statements are true. Supernumerary teeth typically exhibit microdontia (small in size) and are in the maxilla, typically distal to the 3rd molars or between the upper central incisors.
questions.options3: The first statement is true, the second statement is false
questions.options4: The first statement is false, the second statement is true
questions.qsn: Supernumerary teeth usually exhibit microdontia. They are most commonly found in the maxilla.

questions.explaination: Enamel pearls are projections of an exophytic area of enamel on the surface of a root. The area appears as a small round "pearl" of enamel on the surface where enamel isn't normally found.
questions.qsn: Which of the following is an exophytic area of enamel on the root surface?

questions.explaination: Root structure is more likely to demineralize because of a high pH. Enamel demineralizes at a pH of 4.5-5.5. This makes the root surface more susceptible to decay.
questions.qsn: At what pH is a root demineralized?

questions.explaination: Exogenous stains originate from the outside of a tooth. Endogenous stains, such as tetracycline or tooth trauma, originate from inside the tooth.
questions.qsn: Tobacco is considered what type of stain?

questions.explaination: Angular cheilitis is a fungal infection that can be treated with an anti-fungal medication. The other conditions cannot be treated with medications. They will not respond to therapeutic therapies.
questions.qsn: Which of the following conditions would respond to therapeutic diagnosis?

questions.explaination: Dental biofilm is a yellow mass of bacteria that when uncontrolled, can cause dental caries or periodontal infections.
questions.qsn: A dense, nonmineralized complex mass of bacteria that forms a gel like matrix:

questions.explaination: Iron is not a major component of saliva. However, there are trace amounts of the mineral that are found in saliva. A lack of iron in your diet could cause: angular cheilosis, burning tongue, or glossitis
questions.qsn: Which of the following is not a major component of saliva that helps protect against dental caries?

questions.explaination: The IA nerve innervates the pulp of the teeth. The long buccal and the mental nerve bring supply to the surrounding tissues and tongue.
questions.qsn: Which nerve innervates the tooth pulp on the mandible?

questions.explaination: Warton's is a duct that is part of the submandibular gland. It is an opening for saliva and is not a major salivary gland.
questions.qsn: Which of the following is not a major salivary gland?

questions.explaination: Drugs with a high-first past effect have a LARGER oral to parental dose ratio.
questions.options2: False, they have a larger parental dose ratio.
questions.options3: False, they have the same parental dose ratio.
questions.options4: False, drugs do not have a high-first past effect.
questions.qsn: Drugs with a high-first past effect have a smaller oral to parental dose ratio.

questions.explaination: Pharmacokinetics is the movement of a drug in your body, once it is administered. Pharmacodynamics is the study of effects the drug has on your body
questions.qsn: What is the study of how a drug is absorbed, distributed, metabolized and excreted by the body?

questions.explaination: Metabolism will be impaired in relation to the severity of the damage to the liver. A nonfunctioning liver could result in possible toxicity. The metabolism of drugs by means of enzyme reactions, is mostly completed in the liver.
questions.options2: False, only current substance use affects the metabolism of a drug.
questions.options3: False, only previous substance abuse affects the metabolism of a drug.
questions.options4: False, liver disease does not affect the metabolism of a drug.
questions.qsn: Liver disease or previous or current substance abuse may impair the metabolism of a drug.

questions.explaination: The cap stage is the second stage in tooth development. The first is the bud stage where the formation begins. The last stage is the bell stage, where the tissue form and the tooth shape is established.
questions.qsn: The _______ stage of development is when the first signs of an arrangement of cells occur.

questions.explaination: Endoplasmic or endoplasmic reticulum is found throughout a cell and connected to the nucleus. It is not a tissue in the body, but is an important part of cell.
questions.qsn: Which of the following is not a type of tissue found in the body?

questions.explaination: Interradicular fibers are not part of the gingival fiber group. It is actually a reference to the fibers from the cementum and between the roots of teeth to the adjacent bone.
questions.qsn: All of the following are part of the gingival fiber group except:

questions.explaination: Vitamin K is the catalyst for blood clotting. It is derived from food sources in our gut.
questions.qsn: This vitamin is the catalyst for synthesis of blood clotting:

questions.explaination: Pellagra is caused by a chronic lack of the Vitamin B3. It can cause diarrhea, dermatitis and can lead to mental disturbance.
questions.qsn: A deficiency in Vitamin B3 (Niacin) can lead to what disease?

questions.explaination: Peas are rich in vitamin B. Cheese, tofu and kale are all excellent sources of calcium and should be considered when a patient is under nutritional counseling.
questions.qsn: Which of the following is not considered a form of calcium?

questions.explaination: Bidigital palpation is accomplished by using your finger and thumb of both hands. This technique is used to compress and palpate tissue during an extra oral exam.
questions.qsn: What palpation method is used during an extra oral exam that uses the finger and thumbs of both hands?

questions.explaination: Subluxation is the clinical term for dislocation. This can be caused by long dental procedures, which stretch the ligaments around the joint, making it easy for the condyle to dislocate. It is important to inform your patients that they should restrict large movements after long dental procedures.
questions.options3: First statement is true. Second statement is false.
questions.options4: First statement is false. Second statement is true.
questions.qsn: Subluxation is when the condyle of the temporal mandibular joint glides beyond the eminence preventing the jaw from closing. Subluxation can be caused by long dental procedures.

questions.explaination: Vitamin C helps the lining of the gums stay healthy. When a person, especially a smoker, is deficient in this vitamin, the lining is susceptible to bacterial infections, potentially leading to periodontal disease.
questions.qsn: Periodontal disease can be more severe in patients that smoke when they are deficient in this vitamin:

questions.explaination: Cleft lip begins to develop between the 4th and 7th weeks of the first trimester. It becomes evident during the second month of pregnancy.
questions.qsn: What happens when the globular process fails to fuse with the maxillary process during the first trimester of pregnancy?

questions.explaination: Collagen fibers become mineralized and incorporated into the cementum. In teeth, the fibers that are the terminal ends of the principal fibers, that insert into the cementum and into the periosteum of the avelor bone are called Sharpey's fibers.
questions.options3: First statement is true. Second statement is false.
questions.options4: First statement is false. Second statement is true.
questions.qsn: Cementum contains collagen fibers. In teeth, Sharpey's fibers are the terminal ends of the principal fibers that insert into the cementum and into the periosteum of the avelor bone.

questions.explaination: The sagittal plane runs down the midline of our body, creating the left and right side. The Parasagittal plane means any plane that runs parallel to the sagittal plane.
questions.qsn: What plane divides the body into left and right halves?

questions.explaination: The mandibular central incisors are the smallest permanent tooth in the oral cavity. They are the smallest due to the fact that they have a very slight concavity with labial surfaces that are smooth.
questions.qsn: What is the smallest permanent tooth in the mouth?

questions.explaination: Both pharyngeal and esophageal phases of swallowing are under involuntary neuromuscular control. They are both considered involuntary reflex of muscles that allow us to swallow our food fast and easy, causing little harm to surrounding organs.
questions.options3: First statement is true. Second statement is false.
questions.options4: First statement is false. Second statement is true.
questions.qsn: During swallowing, the esophageal phase is under voluntary neuromuscular control. The pharyngeal phase is under involuntary neuromuscular control.

questions.explaination: A psuedopocket is due to gingival enlargement and does not involve the migration of connective tissue attachment and other supporting periodontal tissues.
questions.options3: First statement is true. Second statement is false.
questions.options4: First statement is false. Second statement is true.
questions.qsn: A psuedopocket is produced by edematous gingival tissue. The junction epithelium does not migrate when there is psuedopocketing.

questions.explaination: Mesognathic is when your jaw slightly protrudes in its resting state. This is considered a normal facial profile.
questions.options3: First statement is true. Second statement is false.
questions.options4: First statement is false. Second statement is true.
questions.qsn: A patient with a Class I occlusion would have a facial profile that is mesognathic. Mesognathic is considered to be a normal profile.
